User.name: Avalanche Observer
User.affil: BC Ministry of Transportation NW Avalanche Program

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Profile dug next to avalanche reported to have occurred on 12.28.2022. Avalanche was 75' wide, ran for 125' into the gully. Average crown height was 2.5' and deepest was close to 4'. SS-U -R2-D2. Gully feature allowed snow to pile up deep enough be classified as a D2. Hard to tell what the trigger was. There was a ski track approximately 50' to the the skiers left side. ECTX x 2 although we had failure when prying on the block after the ECTX results. Failed primarily above the ice lens-although the skiers left flank had failure below the ice lens.
Bi-Weekly Snowprofile site

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug low elevation above Butler Fork Access trail. Looking to see how rain affected the faceted layer from November. Facets were 4f- @43cm off of ground and failure was planar with propagation after ECTX under the 1f dirt layer

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche; Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug just below Short Final hhpu. Excellent skiing in 10-30 low density HST ON 20221226 supportive freezing rain crust. Found crust from 2000m to valley bottom. Landed at Short Final regular low landing@2180m HS=135cm, p.u. @1570m.HS=105cm. The compression tests@58 from the ground are on the layer that we have had 22 deep, large avalanches in the last 2 days.

We traversed across the slope and noticed shooting cracks. Initial thought was that it was a storm slab from the previous two days accumulation of 19" @ 2.6 SWE. Closer inspection revealed failure on facets so we decided to do a profile.
Open Glades

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: pit dug after 1kg AE with no results. relatively shallow HS compared to nearby slopes likely due to recent strong SW wind stripping upper elevation S-W aspects near ridgelines. facets near the ground and mid pack show signs of rounding.
bottom of eye opner
Dug towards leeward side. @35 cm: Mid Nov crust nearly all broken down. Lower down valley on Trestle rd~4500 ft: below melt freeze crust (Tues 12/27) is wet snow.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: In a wind-sheltered area.

Pit notes: There was a lot of bush growth in the bottom layer of the snowpack. This will have contributed to the development of depth hoar and facets at the bottom.
Weather Summary: Day began around 11 am with light snow (S-1). Around noon the sun came out for a couple hours. By 2:30 pm clouds were rolling in and visibility dropped dramatically. Ridge top winds were strong westerly.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Heli-skiing with 4 groups in the Powder Pig area on Powder Pig Lo and Pig Bump. Hazard rating 3/3/2. Main concern for large propagations on a PWL of weak facets 80-90 down. Around 10:30, during a 10-15 minute period 10 avalanches remoted either from skiing or heli landings. There were 1x3.5, 2x3, the rest were all 2 to 2.5. The crowns were 80 to 150 cm in depth. Failures were on facets that we think is the Nov. 21 layer. Pit investigation by Matt Peter, Dave Cochrane.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: First day out in Tahoe zone. Previous day was a heavy wet storm.
Start Zone

Some Variable hand hardness due to wind in top ~50 cm storm snow, overall still quite soft.
Pit done on NE aspect of Blueberry Knoll. Encountered moose droppings in bottom of pit. As such snow column may have been disturbed by a moose at some point.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
A stable snowpack is observed. The fairly thick surface crust protects the rest of the snowpack well.
The snowpack is extremely hard in most places and contains a few icy crusts.
During the compression test, the surface crust block failed but did not slide while isolating the column for the test, but this was more of a false alarm due the the small size of the column. Further down it took 30 taps to isolate another block located above a sugary layer, but the block also did not slide. The largest temperature gradient can be found within the layer from about 135 cm to 105 cm, located below this block that isolated at CT30. This layer contains some faceted, sugary snow, but the gradient is not that large, probably due to the deep snowpack at the snowpit location. Places with a thinner snowpack may have a larger gradient and larger faceted snow crystals.
The extended column test took 22 taps to break the surface crust, then on the next tap it broke even more and progressivly got crushed and fell apart by the end of the test, with no smooth sliding. The breakup of the crust was local, only where the column was being hit, and there is no propagation across it (it is only 10 cm thick as well - would be hard to propagate across the entire column).
There is minimal wind loading in a very small amount of places from the surface dusting of snow from a few days ago, but the amount is extremely small and not enough to create dangerous slabs above the surface ice. At the spot of the snowpit there is no wind loading above the surface crust.
Most recent avalanche activity occurred on 12/23.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ltil snjffnun almennt Blfjllum hefur greinilega skafi miki og er v bert melum en safnast lgir og hvlftir, a sst nokrum stum viku gamlan frostinn snj en hann var berandi ofarlega fjallinu. ECT testi kom bort undir skflu @13 en fr eftir stplinum @21 en rann ekki a sjlfdum. sgunar testinu ellti g 45 cm skilinn sem mr sndist vera varhugaverust sagai 80 cm upp urn en stpullin hreifist en rann ekki.
